message.raw:
* Trigger a preparse after remote set_globals()
* Add `interactive` kwarg to Runmanager.get_active_groups so that it can raise
  an exception for remote calls rather than show an error dialog.
* Turn app.preparse_globals_required into a Queue instead of an Event so that
  the number of times it is triggerd can be counted, in order that callers
  can block until all preparsing is complete using .join()
* Add method runmanager.wait_until_preparse_complete() that does this.
* Call app.wait_until_preparse_complete.wait() in handle_n_shots so that the
  result is not subject to a race condition w.r.t. previous remote calls.
* Call app.wait_until_preparse_complete() in handle_engage(). I'm not sure
  it's necessary, but it is strange to be (virtually) clicking engage when the
  button is greyed out, and there may be code (present or future ) that assumes
  you can't do this.
* Do not run blocking remote code such as globals evaluation in the main thread.
  have remote methods only hop into the main thread when required.
* Modify remote handle_error_in_globals to take into account all globals, not
  just those open in tabs.
* remove inmain() call from the remote server's handler - apply inmain calls
  only where they are required within individual handler methods, so that the
  GUI is not blocked by globals parsing.
* remove some unused imports

values.message:
* Trigger a preparse after remote set_globals()
* Add `interactive` kwarg to Runmanager.get_active_groups so that it can raise
  an exception for remote calls rather than show an error dialog.
* Turn app.preparse_globals_required into a Queue instead of an Event so that
  the number of times it is triggerd can be counted, in order that callers
  can block until all preparsing is complete using .join()
* Add method runmanager.wait_until_preparse_complete() that does this.
* Call app.wait_until_preparse_complete.wait() in handle_n_shots so that the
  result is not subject to a race condition w.r.t. previous remote calls.
* Call app.wait_until_preparse_complete() in handle_engage(). I'm not sure
  it's necessary, but it is strange to be (virtually) clicking engage when the
  button is greyed out, and there may be code (present or future ) that assumes
  you can't do this.
* Do not run blocking remote code such as globals evaluation in the main thread.
  have remote methods only hop into the main thread when required.
* Modify remote handle_error_in_globals to take into account all globals, not
  just those open in tabs.
* remove inmain() call from the remote server's handler - apply inmain calls
  only where they are required within individual handler methods, so that the
  GUI is not blocked by globals parsing.
* remove some unused imports

message.raw:
Error if trying to set global that is defined in multiple active groups.

No attempt is made to ensure setting globals is an all-or-nothing affair. Globals
set prior to the error will not be reverted, globals not yet set will not still
be attempted to be set.

message.raw:
Implement `raw` kwarg for `remote.set_globals()` and `remote.get_globals()`.
if set to True (default is False), then globals values are accepted and returned
 as string expressions as stored in the HDF5 file and runmanager GUI.
Otherwise they are treated as python objects, and are `repr()`'d before setting
and `eval()`'d (by runmanager the usual way) upon getting.

Comment out `get_globals_full()` and `set_globals_full()` for now since I'm
not sure what they should do exactly, though obviously setting and getting more
things will need to be added to the remote API in some way.

message.raw:
Fix bug: wrong default port number
Fix bug: set text on item before setting other details, otherwise
on_globals_model_value_changed gets triggered multiple times and the value is
in fact set back and forth three times instead of just once. This also had the
side effect of the latter changes being treated as interactive and thus not
suppressing auto focusing of the units cell as intended.

message.raw:
Split functionality to find comments out of `remove_comments_and_tokenify()`,
into new function `get_comments()`, so that it can be used separately by code that
wants the comments themselves and not just to remove them. This way the remote
server's `set_globals()` can preserve only an expression-final comment (or
comment block) in multi-line expressions.

Use this functionality in RemoteServer.set_globals() to do the above.

Both `remote_comments_and_tokenify()` (used in diffing globals) and `get_comments()`
(used to preserve comments in RemoteServer.set_globals())
are now compatible with multi-line expressions, and so should work with
the word_wrap branch, though some testing would be good.

Example of these two functions in action (with an intentional sytax error in
the code being tokenized):

```python
from runmanager import remove_comments_and_tokenify, find_comments
s = """
foo(a, # 123
    b, # baz
    c)! # qux
    # foo
    """

expr, tokens = remove_comments_and_tokenify(s)
print("without comments:")
for line in expr.splitlines():
    print(repr(line))

print("tokens:", tokens)
comments = find_comments(s)
print("comments only:")
for start, end in comments:
    print(repr(s[start:end]))
```
result:
```
without comments:
''
'foo(a,'
'    b,'
'    c)!'
tokens: ['\n', 'foo', '(', 'a', ',', '\n', 'b', ',', '\n', 'c', ')', '!']
comments only:
' # 123'
' # baz'
' # qux\n    # foo\n    '
```

message.raw:
Basic remote control of runmanager.

Getting and setting of globals, clicking of engage button with:

`runmanager.remote.get_globals()`
`runmanager.remtote.set_globals()`
`runmanager.remote.engage()`

Requires a runmanager host and port to be set in labconfig, otherwise defaults
used. One may also intantiate a runmanager.remote.Client manually to specify
any host and port. The server uses the labconfig port, or a default if not
present.

Require labscript_utils 2.12.5 with a fix for the security-wrapped ZMQClient class

`runmanager.remote.get_globals()`
`runmanager.remtote.set_globals()`
`runmanager.remote.engage()`

Requires a runmanager host and port to be set in labconfig, otherwise defaults
used. One may also intantiate a runmanager.remote.Client manually to specify
any host and port. The server uses the labconfig port, or a default if not
present.

Require labscript_utils 2.12.5 with a fix for the security-wrapped ZMQClient class

every one second. This decreases needless network traffic and zlock log lines,
without risking using the wrong otput folder since it is checked whenever the
user compiles a sequence.

message.raw:
Add the concept of a sequence_index to runmanager.

The sequence index is an incrementing integer starting from zero each day for
each experiment script. It is stored on disk in
<experiment_shot_storage>/<script_name>/.next_sequence_index and accessed using
zlock so that it may be incremented atomically.

The sequence index may be used in the output folder format, which defaults to:
output_folder_format = %%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}, resulting in output
folders like:
<shared_drive>/Experiments/<experiment_name>/<script_name>/2019/03/14/00006

The format string will be fed first to strftime, then a call to .format()
with sequence_index and sequence_timestamp kwargs, where sequence_timestamp is
the time in format '%Y%m%dT%H%M%S', which is the existing format used in
sequence_ids.

Allow the shot filename to also have its format configured, such as:
filename_prefix_format = '%%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}',
resulting in shot filenames like:
2019-03-14_00006_myscript_1.h5

This is similarly passed through strftime and then .format with sequence_index,
sequence_timestamp, and script_basename kwargs.

The pre-set output_folder_format if newly installed labconfigs will be:
%%Y/%%m/%%d/{sequence_index:05d}
which will also be the default if not present in the labconfig file.

The pre-set filename_prefix_format in newly installed labconfigs will be:
%%Y-%%m-%%d_{sequence_index:05d}_{script_basename}
but if not present in labconfig files, {sequence_timestamp}_{script_basename}
will be used to preserve the present behaviour of using the sequence id.

For compatibility with lyse, the sequence_id is still saved to the h5 file, but
other attributes are saved too. These are:

'script_basename': the basename of the script, i.e. myscript
'sequence_date': a string of the date only, i.e. 2019-03-14
'sequence_index': the sequence_index as an integer,
'sequence_id': the sequence_id, i.e. 20190314183955_myscript

The idea is that script_basename, sequence_date and sequence_id become an
alternative to sequence_id as a way of uniquely identifying a shot. lyse
already has a labconfig setting where it uses the sequence_index if present to
index the dataframe (added for the  sake of Spielman fork shots which already
have sequence_index), but it has the issue that shots cannot be fully uniquely
determined by that alone since the date and script name are needed too. So
the date and script name are added to the attrs for this purpose, but sequence_id
is retained.

Refactored runmanager functions to achieve this. There is now a fairly monolithic function
new_sequence_details(), which returns the attrs, folder and filepath prefix for
the given labconfig settings and current time. It's all in one function because
the different pieces all use timestamps, and so to avoid races it either has to be
a single function call or the caller would need to carry around a datetime object.
Since it is not too complicated I made it a single function call, though the callers
are often ignoring one or more of its return values.

Removed generate_sequence_id, since the functions that accept a sequence_id
now accept the sequence_attrs dict instead (one entry of which is the sequence_id).
This and the modifying of other function call signatures is a backward incompatible
change in the sense of the API that runmanager exposes, but is backward-compatible
with how other labscript programs use the runmanager API, i.e. BLACS. So I think
this is acceptable - code using the runmanager API directly may need to change.
We could do a major version bump to indicate this.

message.raw:
Remove use of NetworkOnlyLock, which no longer exists in h5_lock.
This was an accidental break in backward compatibility.

NetworkOnlyLocks worked by acquiring a zlock lock once before many openings
and closings og a h5 file, and those openings and closings used regular in-process
threading.RLocks. This reduced network traffic.

The complexity of reimplementing NetworkOnlyLocks is not worth the slight
performance improvement in my opinion. It would be easier to refactor how
runmanager opens globals to pass around an already opened file instead. It is
always possible to refactor code in this way, so that should be the preferred
approach if we encounter performance issues with repeated file openings in
the future.

message.raw:
Fixed bug where compilation of single shot (aka connection table recompilation) using a globals file that contained globals of lists/arrays resulted in a confusing error.

Previously, the error listed the names of every global group provided that group contains more than one global. This is because we changed the return result of `evaluate_globals` without updating this code.

Now we return the names of globals where the "expansion" column is set. I think this might ignore automatic zip groups, but that probably makes sense as you really only care about the globals that you need to edit, which would still be listed as 'outer' since we don't run the automatic zip group checking code in the API (in fact that code (`guess_expansion_modes`) only exists in the GUI part of runmanager, which means the API/GUI are not actually equivalent when compiling a sequence of shots. Not relevant here....but I'll log an issue about it anyway!)

message.raw:
Implemented the axes tab. Fixes issue #31

* Globals (and zip groups) that are being expanded upon to make maultiple shots are now displayed in the axes tab.
* You can reorder the globals/zip groups which will now change the order in which they are expanded over.
* Expansion occurs over globals as if the hierarchy represented nested for loops in Python (so you iterate over all values in the most indented (lowest) level first for a fixed value in each higher level, etc.)
* You can now shuffle specific globals only.
* The global shuffle is now a tri-state checkbox and will toggle shuffle on/off for all globals/zip groups
* The global shuffle also shuffles the set of shots (as before) if all globals/zip groups are set to shuffle (which ensures that you don't get any grouping by the higher levels as you would only be shuffling the order of values within a single global/zip group)
* The axes tab is saved in the runmanager configuration file (it doesn't make sense to save it in the globals file as the axes tab may show the expansions that span multiple h5 files if you are drawing globals from multiple files)

* The global shuffle is now a tri-state checkbox and will toggle shuffle on/off for all globals/zip groups
* The global shuffle also shuffles the set of shots (as before) if all globals/zip groups are set to shuffle (which ensures that you don't get any grouping by the higher levels as you would only be shuffling the order of values within a single global/zip group)
* The axes tab is saved in the runmanager configuration file (it doesn't make sense to save it in the globals file as the axes tab may show the expansions that span multiple h5 files if you are drawing globals from multiple files)
